fields.title: Kagan Cooperative Learning: Inside-Outside Circle & Talking Chips
fields.description: Kagan structures are techniques and activities teachers can use in their classrooms to keep students engaged, active, and have fun while they are learning

fields.title: Think Pair Share Explained
fields.description: This video provides a succinct explanation for students about how to participate in THINK PAIR SHARE activities.

fields.title: World Cafe
fields.description: This video shows how to introduce students to the world cafe teaching protocol.

fields.title: Gallery Walk
fields.description: This video explains the Gallery Walk Protocol

fields.title: Quiz Quiz Trade
fields.description: This video explains the Quiz Quiz Trade Protocol

fields.title: Teach Like a Champion Technique 1 - No Opt Out
fields.description: No Opt Out is a useful tool to get all students to the right answer, as often as possible, even if only to repeat the correct answer.

fields.title: Teach Like a Champion Technique 2 - Right is Right
fields.description: Right is Right is a technique teachers can use to set and defend a high standard of correctness by only naming "right" those answers which are truly and completely right.

fields.title: Teach Like a Champion Technique 36 - 100 Percent (Part 1 of 4)
fields.description: This video explains how to have an authoratative voice in the classroom without resorting to draconian discipline.

fields.title: Narrating
fields.description: Narrating is extremely effective in kindergarten but can also be used in other grades. Narrating is a teaching strategy that takes time to get used to. Keep practicing and you will become a natural at it.

fields.title: Creating a Positive Learning Environment
fields.description: When students’ mental, emotional, and physical needs are met, they’re more likely to love school—and they learn more.

fields.title: TrillEDU: Culturally Responsive Pedagogy...
fields.description: This video highlights the importance of being culturally responsive in the field of student development.

fields.title: Introduction to Culturally Relevant Pedagogy
fields.description: Education experts Jackie Jordan Irvine, Geneva Gay and Kris Gutierrez explain how to make culturally relevant pedagogy a reality in your classroom.

fields.title: Implicit Bias: Peanut Butter, Jelly and Racism
fields.description: What is implicit bias? NYT/POV's Saleem Reshamwala unscrews the lid on the unfair effects of our subconscious.

fields.title: Culturally Responsive Teaching
fields.description: Learning about culturally responsive practices can advance gender sensitivity among educators. With this awareness, educators can recognize and avoid the unconscious behaviors that often contribute to climates unfavorable for youth in STEM classrooms or activities.

fields.title: My Culturally Responsive Classroom
fields.description: How to create a culturally responsive classroom.

fields.title: 8 Essential Components of an Effective Lesson Plan
fields.description: How to create an effective lesson plan.

fields.title: Bloom's Taxonomy: Why, How, & Top Examples
fields.description: Bloom's Taxonomy is fully explained in detail for educators across various disciplines. The video answer the question of why should teachers and educators use Blooms Taxonomy in their practice.

fields.title: What A 'Flipped' Classroom Looks Like
fields.description: This video takes a look inside Clintondale Highschool where teachers record lectures for students to watch online outside of class; and what was once considered homework is now done in class, allowing students to work through assignments together and ask teachers for help if they run into questions.

fields.title: Blended Learning: Making it Work in Your Classroom
fields.description: A school-wide approach to blended learning that allows teachers the flexibility to define and implement online instruction that meets their students needs.

fields.title: Differentiating Instruction: It’s Not as Hard as You Think
fields.description: In this video, teacher and author Larry Ferlazzo explains that differentiating instruction is really about getting to know your students and making decisions, often in the moment, based on what they need. He offers some low-lift strategies he’s learned over the years for making activities accessible for students with all types of gifts and challenges.

fields.title: Data-Driven Instruction: Dr. Robert J. Marzano
fields.description: Dr. Marzano explains Data-Driven Instruction.

fields.title: Data-Driven Instruction: Dr. Robert J. Marzano
fields.description: Data-Driven Instruction explained by renown educator Dr. Marzano.

fields.title: Investing Students in Data
fields.description: How to get students to buy into data.

fields.title: Grading Hacks For Teachers
fields.description: High school & middle school teachers! Don't get buried by the ever-growing stack of student papers. Instead, borrow these tips from an experienced high school English teacher who has reclaimed her life while still giving rich, meaningful feedback to her students.

fields.title: How to Make Grading Easier
fields.description: All teachers understand the feeling of having piles, and piles of papers that need to be graded.  In this video, there are four tips that you can do RIGHT NOW to make grading a bit easier!
